translated: Biographies of Eminent Monks, Scroll 11
Compiled by Shi Huijiao, a monk from Jiaxiang Temple in Kuaiji, Liang Dynasty
Chapter on Meditation Practice, 21 people; Chapter on Vinaya, 13 people
Zhu Senxian, originally surnamed Fu, was a person from northern China.
He was upright, austere, and good at observing precepts. He ate vegetarian food, recited sutras, and practiced meditation as his main task.
He often stayed alone in mountains and forests, practicing austerities outside of human society.
Sometimes he entered meditation for several days, yet he still had no appearance of hunger.
At that time, Liu Yao's troops ravaged the Western Capital, and the court and the people were in chaos.
Senxian, at the end of the Tai Xing era of the Jin dynasty, went south to the Jiangzuo region.
He again visited famous mountains, practicing his usual austerities.
Later, he encountered a prolonged illness and focused his thoughts on the Western Paradise, with a very painful mind.

He saw AmitÄbha Buddha descend with his true appearance, his light illuminating his body, and all his suffering was completely healed. That night he got up, bathed, and told those who lived with him and attended to him about what he saw, and also explained the causes and effects of the precepts, with very precise words.
The next morning, he peacefully sat and passed away.
There was a special fragrance in the room, which did not cease for more than ten days.
Bo Sengguang, Bo Sengguang, also called Tan Guang, it is unknown where he was from.
When young, he practiced meditation.
In the Yonghe period of the Jin dynasty, he traveled to Jiangdong and took refuge in Shicheng Mountain in Shan.
The mountain people all said that in this area there used to be disasters caused by ferocious beasts, and the mountain god was also violent, so human traces had long been cut off.
Guang had no fear at all, hired people to clear and cut, and went forward with his staff.
After walking a few li, suddenly there was a great wind and rain, and a group of tigers howled.
Guang saw a stone chamber to the south of the mountain, and stayed there, sitting in meditation with palms joined, as a place to rest his spirit.
When it rained the next morning, he entered the village to beg for food and returned to the chamber in the evening.
After three days, he dreamed of the mountain god, sometimes in the form of a tiger and sometimes in the body of a snake, all coming to frighten Guang.
Guang was not afraid of any of them.
After three more days, he dreamed of the mountain god saying that he had moved to Hanshi Mountain in Zhang'an County and was offering the chamber to him.
After that, firewood gatherers and travelers all came to pay respect to him.
Those who enjoyed meditation and came to study built thatched huts beside the chamber, gradually forming a temple, which was named Yinyue.
Guang would enter samÄdhi every time and would not arise for seven days.
He stayed in the mountain for fifty-three years, living to the age of one hundred and ten.
At the end of the Taiyuan era of the Jin dynasty, he passed away sitting upright with his robe covering his head.
The monks all thought he was in samÄdhi as usual.
After seven days, they wondered why he was not getting up, so they went together to look at him. His complexion was as usual, but there was no breath in his nose.
Although the spirit had departed for a long time, his physical body did not decay.
In the second year of Xiaojian in the Song dynasty, Guo Hong served in Yan. He entered the mountain to pay homage and tried to poke his chest with a walking stick. A gust of wind suddenly arose.
His clothes and robes scattered, leaving only white bones.
Hong was greatly ashamed and afraid, so he collected them in a room, piled bricks outside them and plastered them, and painted his image. It still exists today.
Zhu Tanyou Zhu Tanyou, also known as Fayou, was from Dunhuang.
He practiced asceticism from a young age and studied meditation.
Later, he traveled to the south of the Yangtze River and stayed at Shicheng Mountain in Yan, begging for food and sitting in meditation.
Once, he went to a family that raised centipedes to beg for food.
After Tanyou finished reciting the prayer, a centipede suddenly jumped out from the food.
Tanyou ate it without any problems.
Later, he moved to the Stone Chamber on Mount Chi-cheng in Shi-feng to sit in meditation.
There were dozens of ferocious tigers crouching in front of You, but he recited the sutra as usual.
One tiger was sleeping alone, and You knocked on the tiger's head with his ruyi and asked why it was not listening to the sutra. Soon, the group of tigers all left.
After a while, a huge snake appeared, more than ten feet in circumference, coiling around and raising its head towards You for half a day before leaving again.
Later, a deity appeared in person and said to You:
The Dharma Master's majestic virtue is weighty, and he has come to stay on this mountain. I will push my room to offer it to you.
You said:
I am searching for mountains, hoping to meet you. Why don't we live together?
The deity said:
I am not like that, but my subordinates have not yet been influenced by the Dharma, and it is difficult to control their words.
When people come and go from afar, they may encroach on each other.
The ways of humans and spirits are different, so I am leaving.
You said:
What deity are you originally?
How long have you lived here, and where do you intend to move to?
The deity said:
I am the son of Xiadi, and have lived on this mountain for over two thousand years.
Hanshi Mountain is where my uncle resides, and I will go live there.
He then returned to the temple at the foot of the mountain.
As they parted, he held You's hand and gave him three boxes of incense. Then he blew his conch shell and left, soaring into the clouds.
On Mount Chicheng, there is a solitary rock standing alone, towering above a thousand clouds.
You climbed the rock, made a ladder out of stones, ascended the peak, sat in meditation, and had bamboo pipes to transmit water for his daily use.
More than ten people came to study Chan with him.
Wang Xizhi heard about this and went there on purpose. He looked up to the lofty peak, paid his respects, and returned.
Mount Chicheng is connected to Mount Tiantai, the cascading waterfalls, the spiritual stream, and the four bright peaks.
But Mount Tiantai has steep cliffs and towering peaks that seem to touch the sky.
According to an old legend:
Above it was a fine monastery, inhabited by those who had attained the Way.
Although there was a stone bridge spanning the stream, the horizontal stone blocked people, and moreover the green moss was slippery. Since ancient times, no one had been able to reach it.
When You arrived at the bridge, he heard a voice in the air saying:
I know your sincerity is sincere, but you have not yet been able to cross.
Ten years from now, you will come by yourself.
You's heart was disappointed, and he stayed there for the night. He heard the sound of chanting the word sa while practicing the Way.
In the morning, he wanted to go forward again, and saw a man with white beard and eyebrows, who asked You where he was going.
You fully answered his intention.
The man said:
Your body is subject to birth and death, how can you go there?
I am the mountain god, so I am telling you.
You then withdrew.
On the way, he passed a stone chamber and rested there after noon.
Suddenly, the clouds and mist gathered and the chamber rang throughout.
You's expression was undisturbed.
The next morning, he saw a person wearing a single robe come, saying:
This is my residence. I was not at home yesterday, so I caused you to be disturbed. I am deeply ashamed.
Zhaoyou said:
If this is your house, please return it to me.
The spirit said:
My house has already been moved. Please stay here.
Zhaoyou stayed for a while.
Zhaoyou always regretted not being able to cross the stone bridge.
Later, after purifying himself for many days, he wanted to go again.
He saw the horizontal stone open up, allowing him to cross the bridge a little. He saw a monastery and a divine monk, just as he had said before.
He then burned incense and had a meal together with them.
After the meal, the divine monk said to Zhaoyou:
After ten years, you will come here by yourself. You cannot stay now.
Then he returned.
He looked back at the horizontal stone, which closed up again as before.
In the Taiyuan era of the Jin dynasty, there was an ominous star. The emperor decreed to all countries:
A virtuous monk was asked to hold a repentance ritual to avert the disaster.
Yu then sincerely prayed and received a response.
On the morning of the sixth day, he saw a young boy in blue clothes come and repent, saying:
I rashly disturbed the Dharma master. The star will retreat this evening.
A separate account says:
The one who averted the star was Bo Sengguang.
This is not yet clear.
Yu died in a mountain chamber at the end of the Taiyuan era.
His corpse was still sitting upright, and his entire body was green.
At the end of the Yixi era of the Jin dynasty, the recluse Shen Shibiao entered the mountain and climbed the cliff, and saw Yu's uncorrupted corpse.
Later, those who wanted to go and see it were always confused by the clouds and mist, and no one could catch a glimpse of it.
At that time, there were also Hui Kai and Hui Zhen, who were also skilled in meditation.
They entered Lingbi Mountain in Yuzhang and each built a meditation hut, which is still there today.
Shi Huigui, Shi Huigui 4, was not sure where he was from.
He stayed at a large temple in Chang'an.
His precepts and conduct were pure and clean, and he often stayed in mountains and valleys, practicing the practice of meditation.
There was a headless ghost that came, but Wei's expression did not change. He said to the ghost:
Since you have no head, you don't have the trouble of a headache. How wonderful!
The ghost then disappeared and came back as a ghost without a belly, only with hands and feet.
Wei said again:
Since you have no belly, you don't have the worries of the five internal organs. How joyful!
In an instant, it turned into another form, and Wei sent them all away according to their words.
Later, when the weather was very cold and snowy, a woman came to ask for lodging.
Her appearance was upright, her clothes were bright, her demeanor was graceful and elegant, and she called herself a heavenly maiden:
Because the superior person has virtue, the heavens sent me to come and comfort you.
She spoke of lustful matters and encouraged him to change his mind.
Wei Zhi was upright and resolute, with a single mind undisturbed, and said to the woman:
My mind is like dead ashes, not to be moved by a leather bag.
The woman then soared into the clouds and left, looking back and sighing:
The ocean can dry up, Mount Sumeru can be overturned, but this superior person's resolve is firm and upright.
Later, in the third year of Long'an in the Jin dynasty, he traveled to the Western Regions with Faxian, and his end is unknown.
Shi Xianhu, whose surname was Sun, was a person from Liangzhou.
He came to stay at Yanxing Temple in Guanghan, always practicing meditation as his occupation, and was also good at Vinaya practice, without the slightest transgression.
He died in the fifth year of Long'an in the Jin dynasty, and at the time of his death, five-colored light shone throughout the entire temple.
He left instructions to have his body cremated, and his disciples carried it out. His bones were all consumed, but only one finger remained unburned, so it was buried under the pagoda.
Zhi Tanlan, a person from Qingzhou.
Vegetarian, fond of meditation, recited scriptures of 300,000 words.
During the Taiyuan period of the Jin dynasty, he traveled to Shan, later rested at Chi-cheng Mountain in Shi-feng, saw a place with clear forests and springs, and lived there.
After several days, he suddenly saw a person, several feet tall, scolding Tanlan to leave.
He also saw various strange-looking birds and beasts, using them to scare Tanlan several times.
Seeing Tanlan calmly at ease, he then knelt and bowed, saying:
Zhu Qi Wang is my uncle, now going to Wei-qing Mountain to see him, pushing this place to offer to you.
Three years later, he suddenly heard the sound of carriages and horses coming from afar, with followers filling the peaks.
Soon someone wearing a cap claimed to be Zhu Qi Wang, having already come forward, his wife, children, and twenty-three others, all with dignified appearances surpassing the world.
When they arrived at Lan's place, after exchanging greetings, Lan asked where they were staying.
They replied:
On Mount Weiqing in Le'an County.
For a long time, we have admired your reputation and now, together with our family, we respectfully entrust ourselves to you, requesting to receive the precepts of taking refuge.
Lan then bestowed them.
After receiving the teachings, they gave him ten thousand coins and two containers of honey, took their leave, and departed.
They then heard the sound of flutes and pipes, resounding through the mountains and valleys.
The ten or so people in Lan's meditation group all heard and saw it together.
In the Yuanxi period of the Jin dynasty, he passed away on the mountain at the age of eighty-three.
Shi Fa Xu, Shi Fa Xu, Shi Fa Xu, with the surname Hun, was a person from Gaochang.
He was virtuous, pure, and meticulous, eating vegetarian food and practicing meditation.
Later, he entered Shu and practiced austerities at the Liu Shi Tomb, where tigers and rhinos in the mountains and valleys did not harm him.
He recited the Lotus Sutra, the Vimalakirti Sutra, and the Suvará¹‡a-prabhÄsa-sÅ«tra.
He always stayed in a stone chamber, both meditating and reciting.
In the middle of summer, he passed away in the room, and his body did not smell for seven days.
There was a fragrance on the left side of the corpse, which lasted for ten days before stopping. Every evening, it emitted light, illuminating several miles.
The villagers then built a tomb and stupa over the corpse.
Shi Xuan Gao, Shi Xuan Gao 8, with the surname Wei, originally named Ling Yu, was a person from Wan Nian in Feng Yi.
His mother, Lady Kou, originally believed in non-Buddhist teachings.
When she first married into the Wei family, she gave birth to a daughter, who was Gao's older sister.
As soon as she was born, she believed in Buddhism and made a vow for her mother, wishing that her family would have no different views and be able to uphold the great Dharma.

In the third year of Hong Shi of the pseudo Qin, her mother dreamed of an Indian monk scattering flowers filling the room. When she woke up, she became pregnant. On the eighth day of the second month in the fourth year, she gave birth to a boy.
Suddenly there was a strange fragrance in the house, and light shone on the walls until dawn before it stopped.
The mother, taking the auspicious signs of the child's birth, named him Ling Yu.
At that time, people respected him and called him Shigao again.
At the age of twelve, he bid farewell to his parents to enter the mountains, but they did not allow it for a long time.
One day, a student stayed at Gao's house and said he wanted to hide in Zhongchang Mountain.
Gao's parents then entrusted him to the student.
That night, everyone in the village saw them escorting each other. The next morning, people from the village all came to look for Gao.
Gao's parents said:
We already saw them off yesterday, why are you looking for them again today?
The villagers said:
We didn't know he was leaving, how could we have already seen him off?
Gao's parents then realized that the welcoming and seeing off the night before were done by spirits.
When Gao first arrived at the mountain, he wanted to leave home.
The mountain monk did not allow it, saying:
Without your parents' permission, I cannot ordain you.
Gao then temporarily returned home and requested to enter the path.
After twenty days, he finally accomplished his original intention.
Having turned his back on worldly affairs, he changed his name to Xuangao.
He was intelligent and knowledgeable, and did not need to study hard.
By the age of fifteen, he was already expounding the Dharma for the monks on the mountain.
After receiving full ordination, he focused on Chan and the Vinaya.
He heard that Chan Master Buddhabhadra was teaching at Shiyang Temple in the pass, so Gao went to study with him.
In just a few days, he had a profound understanding of Chan.
Buddhabhadra praised him, saying:
Excellent, Buddha's disciple, you are able to deeply understand like this.
Then, with a humble attitude, he pushed aside the honor and did not accept the teacher's offerings.
Gao then traveled with his staff to Xiping and secluded himself on Mount Maichi.
Over a hundred mountain students revered his teachings and received his Chan teachings.

At that time, there was a monk named Shi Tanhong from Chang'an, a great monk of the Qin land, who was in seclusion on this mountain. He met with Gao and became friends with him, sharing the same practice.
At that time, the Buddha's teachings flourished in the area west of the pass, reaching as far as the Liang lands.
There was a foreign Chan master named Tanwubi.
He came to their country and led a group of disciples, teaching them Chan practice.
However, the profound and wonderful state of samÄdhi was rarely practiced by monks in Longxi.
Gao then wanted to lead his own group and follow Vipula to learn the Dharma.
Within a few days, Vipula returned and told Gao his intention.
At that time, there were two monks in Henan who, although they had the appearance of Å›ramaá¹‡as, had power equal to that of a false prime minister.
They indulged their desires and violated the precepts, and were quite jealous of learned monks.
After Vipula returned west to Sheyi, the two monks then slandered Xuan Gao to the crown prince Man of Henan, saying that he was gathering a crowd and would bring disaster to the country.
Man believed the slander and wanted to harm Gao, but his father did not agree. He then banished Gao to Tangshan in Linyang, Hebei.
The elders of the mountain had a legend that it was the dwelling place of a group of immortals.
Gao's disciples and followers, numbering three hundred, went to live in the mountain hut.
His spirit remained calm, and his meditation and wisdom became even fresher. His loyal sincerity moved the unseen world, and there were many spiritual wonders.
The bell rang without being struck, and the incense naturally had a fragrance.
Arhats and immortals often came to visit.
Fierce beasts were tamed, and poisonous locusts were eliminated.
Among Gao's disciples, more than a hundred people mastered the six methods.
There was Xuan Shao, a person from Longxi, Qinzhou.
He studied all kinds of meditation and had mastery of spiritual powers.
He could produce water from his fingertips for Gao to wash, and the water was fragrant and pure, incomparably better than usual.
He often obtained extraordinary flowers and incense to offer to the Three Jewels.
There were eleven others like Shao who had spiritual wonders.
Shao later entered Tangshushan and passed away like a cicada shedding its shell.
In the past, Dharma Master Tanhong of Chang'an moved to Min and Shu, and his teachings spread to Chengdu.
The Prince of Henan relied on his high reputation and sent envoys to welcome him.
When Hong heard that Gao had been expelled, he vowed to defend his innocence. He disregarded the difficulties of the plank road and braved the dangers to follow his master's orders.
After arriving in Henan, the host and guest formalities were completed. He then said to the king:
Since you have profound insight and far-reaching discernment, why would you believe slander and abandon the virtuous?
The reason I traveled thousands of miles is precisely to present this one white [elephant].
The king and prince were ashamed and remorseful. They immediately sent envoys to Gao, humbly apologizing and inviting Gao to return to the prefecture.
Since Gao had a broad mind of universal salvation, he forgot his anger and accepted the order.
When he was about to leave the mountain, the grasses and trees in the mountain collapsed and fell, and a landslide blocked the road.
Gao chanted a vow, saying:
I vow to propagate the Way. How can I be obstructed by this place?
Then the wind subsided, the road opened, and he gradually returned to the country.
The king and the people welcomed him along the road.
The inside and outside [of the country] respectfully served him and revered him as the national teacher.
After completing his transformation in Henan, he proceeded to travel to the Liang region.
Juqu Mengxun deeply respected him and held assemblies for the eminent guests, giving rise to lofty and excellent understanding.
At that time, there was Fan Sengyin in the Western Sea, who also studied under Gao.
With a narrow mind and limited capacity, he considered himself content with little, and claimed to have attained arhatship and exhausted the Chan teachings.
Gao then secretly used his spiritual powers to cause Sengyin to fully see in his samÄdhi the different Dharma gates taught by the buddhas in the boundless worlds of the ten directions.
Sengyin searched for what he saw during one summer, but was never able to exhaust it, and only then realized that the water of samÄdhi has no bottom. He felt great shame and fear.
At that time, the Wei barbarian Toba Tao usurped power in Pingcheng, and his troops invaded the territory of Liang.
Tao's uncle, the King of Yangping, invited Gao to return to the pseudo capital together.
After arriving in Pingcheng, he greatly spread the Chan teachings.
The pseudo crown prince Toba Huang served Gao as his teacher.
One time, Huang was slandered and suspected by his father, so he told Gao,
The suffering of empty slander, how can I escape it?
Gao ordered the performance of the Golden Light Repentance.

For seven days they earnestly repented, and Tao then dreamed that his grandfather and father both held swords, their majestic appearance fierce, and asked, Why do you believe slander and falsely suspect the prince?
Tao was startled awake and gathered all the ministers to tell them about the dream.
The ministers all said, The prince is innocent, it truly is as the imperial spirit has decreed.
Tao then had no further doubts about the prince.
This was indeed the power of Gao's sincere feelings.
Tao then issued a decree saying:
I have inherited the legacy of my ancestors' heavy light, and wish to proclaim the great foundation, flourishing for myriad generations.
Although my martial achievements are brilliant, the literary teachings have not yet been fully developed, which is not the way to promote the governance of great peace.
Now that the realm is peaceful and the people are prosperous, it is appropriate to establish institutions as the law for myriad generations.
Yin and yang have coming and going, the four seasons have succession.
Entrusting the heir with the task of being wise, safely passing on to him, is the way to rest the weary and make it last long.
It is the unchanging imperial code of ancient and modern times.

Our meritorious ministers have been laboring for a long time. They should retire to their homes, enjoy their high ranks, nourish their spirits, and nurture their longevity, discussing the Way and presenting their strategies.
They need not again personally take on the arduous duties of government officials.

Let the Crown Prince assist in managing the myriad affairs and preside over the hundred offices, further selecting worthy and virtuous ones to fill the various positions, choosing people to be appointed and promoted or demoted.
Therefore Confucius said, The young are to be feared.
How can we know that those who come later will not be like those of today?
Thus, the officials of the court and the common people all addressed the Crown Prince as their subject.
The memorial was written on white paper to distinguish it.

At that time, Cui Hao and Kou Tian, the Celestial Master, had already gained favor with Toba Tao. Fearing that when Hui ascended the throne, he would take away their authority, they slandered, saying:
The prince's previous actions truly had a scheming mind.
But he formed a bond with Master Gao's way, causing the late emperor to descend in a dream.
If such discussions and events are not eradicated, they will surely become a great harm.
Tuo then accepted it and was greatly enraged. He immediately ordered the arrest of Gao.
Gao had previously secretly told his disciples:
The Buddha Dharma should decline. Master Gao and I will be at the forefront of this calamity.
At that time, those who heard it could not help but sigh.
At that time, there was a monk named Shi Huichong from Liangzhou, who was the teacher of Han Wande, the Minister of Civil Affairs of the pseudo Wei government.
Since his virtue was next to Gao, he was also suspected and obstructed.
In the fifth year of the pseudo Tai Ping era, in the ninth month, Gao and Master Chong were both imprisoned.
On the fifteenth day of that month, they were executed at the eastern edge of Ping Cheng, at the age of forty-three.
This was the twenty-first year of the Yuan Jia era of the Song Dynasty.
On that evening, the disciples did not know.
At the third watch of the night, they suddenly saw light circling the stupa where Gao Xian was staying three times, and then entering the meditation cave.
Then they heard a voice in the light saying:
I have already passed away.
The disciples then realized he had already transformed, and wailed in grief.
Afterwards, they welcomed the corpse to the wilderness south of the city, bathed it, and buried it.
They also made arrangements for Chong, placing him separately in another place.
The monks and laypeople of the entire capital all sighed in amazement.

Disciple Xuan Chang was then in Yunzhong, six hundred li away from the Wei capital. In the morning, he suddenly saw a person come and tell him about the change, and was given a horse for the six hundred li journey.
Thus, he whipped the horse and returned. In the evening, he arrived at the capital and saw that the master had already passed away. He grieved and fainted.
Then he said to his fellow students, weeping:
Now that the Dharma has been extinguished, can it be revived again?
If it can be revived, please have the Venerable rise and sit.
The virtue of the preceptor is not that of an ordinary person, you must surely illuminate it.
After saying this, Gao's eyes slightly opened, and his complexion returned to joy.
His body broke out in sweat, and the sweat smelled very fragrant.
After a while, he sat up and said to his disciples:
The great Dharma responds to transformations, flourishing and declining with conditions.
Flourishing and declining are in the traces, but the principle is always tranquil.
But I think that before long, you will also be like me. Only Xuanchang will be able to go south.
After your deaths, the Dharma will flourish again.
Cultivate your minds well, do not regret it in the middle.
After saying this, he lay down and passed away.
The next day, they moved the coffin and wanted to cremate it, but the national regulations did not allow it, so they built a tomb and buried it there.
The monks and laypeople grieved and wept, looking at the place where he disappeared.
There was a Å›ramaá¹‡a named Fadai, who was the Vinaya Master of the pseudo-state. He had long admired Gao but had not yet received his teachings.
Suddenly hearing of his death, he wept and said:
After the sage's passing, on what should we rely?
For many days he did not eat, always calling out:
The supreme sage is free, why can he not appear once?
In response, he saw Gao flying in the air and arriving.
Da bowed in repentance and begged for salvation, wishing to be rescued.
Gao said:
Your karma is heavy and difficult to save, what can be done?
From now on, rely on the painful repentance of the Vaipulya [sutras], and you will receive a lighter retribution.
Da said:
If I escape painful retribution, I wish you would have compassion and save me.
Gao said:
Do not forget everyone, how can I alone be in a different place?
Da also said:
Where were Dharma Master and Venerable Chong both reborn?
Gao said:
I vowed to be born in a bad world to save sentient beings, so I was reborn in JambudvÄ«pa.
Venerable Chong always prayed for rebirth in the Pure Land, and his wish has been fulfilled.
Da also asked:
I wonder which stage the Dharma Master has already reached?
Gao said:
My disciples themselves know.
After saying this, he suddenly disappeared.
Damimi asked Gao's disciples, who all said he was a bodhisattva who had attained forbearance.
By the seventh year of the Wei Dynasty's Tai Ping era, the Toba clan indeed destroyed Buddhism, just as Gao had said.

At that time, in the state of Hexi, there was a monk named Tanyao under the rule of Juqu Maoqian, who was also known for his Chan practice. The false grand preceptor Zhang Tan revered him as his teacher.
Shi Sengzhou, Shi Sengzhou, unknown person.
He had a lofty and resolute nature with extraordinary will and conduct.
Yet he concealed his light and hid his traces, and no one could know him.
He always sat in meditation in the peak of Mount Song.
When the Wei barbarians were about to destroy Buddhism, Zhou said to his disciples:
A great calamity is coming.
So he entered Cold Mountain with several dozen of his followers.
The mountain is 400 li southwest of Chang'an, with dangerous valleys and gorges, inaccessible to troops, so he settled there.
Soon after, the Wei invaders ran amok, and all who stayed were killed.
Afterwards, they repented and exterminated the Cui clan, and revived Buddhism.
The fake Yongchang King garrisoned Chang'an, and upon imperial order was about to rebuild, searching for monks.
At that time, it was said that there was a monk on Cold Mountain with extraordinary virtue, so the king sent envoys to invite him.
Zhou declined on the grounds of old age and illness, and ordered his disciple Seng Liang to leave the mountain in response to the summons.
Later, Zhou was about to die and told his disciples:
I am leaving.
That evening, fire was seen coming out from behind the rope bed and burning his body. It took three days to completely burn out.
The smoke and flames reached the sky, but the room was not destroyed.
His disciples collected the remaining ashes and built a brick stupa.
His disciple Seng Liang, whose surname was Li, was from Chang'an and studied under Seng Zhou.
Initially, when King Yongchang invited monks, none dared to respond, all saying that since the Buddha Dharma had just begun, there were concerns about unforeseen consequences.
Liao said:
The transmission of the Dharma relies on people, and today is the right time.
If we are to be executed, I will take responsibility for it myself;
if we are spared, then the Dharma will have a chance to flourish again.
Furthermore, Seng Zhou encouraged him, so he followed the envoy to Chang'an.
Before arriving, the king and the people swept the streets and lanes, and waited in their houses to welcome him.
The king personally went out of his way to greet him, touching his feet in respect.
Liao explained the consequences of misfortune and blessings, and instructed them on cause and effect.
His words were concise yet reasonable, harmonious yet urgent.
The listeners were moved to tears, each unable to contain themselves.
Then he restored the old temples and invited monks.
The great Dharma of the Guanzhong region flourished again, all due to Liao's efforts.
Shi Huitong, Shi Huitong, a person from Guanzhong.
She stayed at Taimiao Temple in Chang'an, eating vegetarian food, reciting spells, and reciting the Zengyi Ahan Sutra.
At first, she consulted with the Chan master Huizhao from Liangzhou to receive the Chan teachings, and she was well-versed in the meditation practices of the Dharma gate.
She always prayed for rebirth in the Pure Land and wished to dwell in that country.
When she was slightly ill, she saw a person in her meditation, whose appearance was very dignified, who said to her, The right time has come.
In a moment, she saw the Buddha AmitÄbha, whose radiance was shining.

The great enlightenment is obscure and formless, responding to the distant and valuing forgetting and tranquility.
